pgTitle: List of domestic works by Alfred Waterhouse

rows.text: Waterhouse's first new build; a country house for Elizabeth Head. Extended in 1890.

Ince-in-Makerfield, Wigan, Greater Manchester
{{coord|53.5329|-2.6169|name=Lodge and gates, Ince Cemetery}}
File:Former Lodge at Ince Cemetery, Warrington Road, Lower Ince - geograph.org.uk - 78780.jpg
Two-storey stone lodge with a slate roof. The gates are in cast iron and are "elaborate".
A country house built for Christopher Bushell, a Liverpool wine merchant in sandstone with a green slate roof. It has two storeys and a tower.

Neston, Cheshire
{{coord|53.2992|-3.04682|name=Main Lodge, Hinderton Hall, Neston}}
Built in sandstone with a green slate roof in a cruciform plan.

Neston, Cheshire
{{coord|53.2987|-3.0409|name=Back Lodge, Hinderton Hall, Neston}}
Built in sandstone with a green slate roof in an L-shaped plan.

Neston, Cheshire
{{coord|53.2958|-3.0382|name=Quarry Lodge, Hinderton Hall, Neston}}
Built in sandstone with a green slate roof in an L-shaped plan.
A country house for James Bell overlooking Derwentwater. Its sitting room is on the top floor to take advantage of the view.
An Italianate house for G. G. Cunningham.
Built in stone with a tiled roof and brick chimneystack. It has two storeys and attics.
Cottages and estate office as part of the Easneye Estate. T-shaped in brick with two storeys.
Built for the Quaker Joseph Pease.
A suburban mansion for the lawyer W. G. Bateson. It is built in polychromatic brick with slate roofs, and was later divided into apartments.
Built as a country house for Alfred Backhouse, in the 20th century it was used as a hospital, and later as a hotel. It is a red brick building with slate roofs.
Used as a dower house for the Bolesworth Estate. It has an irregular plan, and is constructed in brick with sandstone dressings and a tiled roof.

Broxton, Cheshire
{{coord|53.0865|-2.7658|name=Stable and coach house, Bankhead, Broxton}}
Built for the Bolesworth Estate. A single-storey L-shaped building in red brick with tiled roofs.

Grappenhall and Thelwall, Cheshire
{{coord|53.3763|-2.5332|name=Thelwall Heys, Cheshire}}
A country house in red-brown brick with yellow and blue brick banding, sandstone dressings, and a slate roof.
A house dating from about 1720, re-cased, altered and extended. Later used as student accommodation.

A large country house for J. W. Pease. It is a brick building with slate roofs. The frontage is of seven bays, and the building in High Victorian style. Associated with the house are a kitchen courtyard, a conservatory, and a gatehouse.

Newcastle upon Tyne
{{coord|54.9726|-1.6696|name=Royal Victoria School for the Blind, Newcastle upon Tyne}}

This originated as the home of Dr Thomas Hodgkin, who later gave the house to the Royal Victoria School for the Blind. It is constructed in sandstone and has a slate roof. The building is in two storeys with attics.

Newcastle upon Tyne
{{coord|54.9729|-1.6691|name=Royal Victoria School for the Blind, Newcastle upon Tyne}}
A sandstone house with a slate roof in one storey.

Stanstead Abbots, Hertfordshire
{{coord|51.7955|0.0040|name=Lodge to Easneye, Stanstead Abbots}}

Built as a country house for Thomas Fowell Buxton, it is constructed in red brick with black brick diapering, and has tiled roofs. Its plan is asymmetrical in three blocks. It has been used later as a college.

Stanstead Abbots, Hertfordshire
{{coord|51.8030|0.0007|name=Stables, Easneye, Stanstead Abbots}}
An L-shaped building in red brick with a tiled roof.

A mansion built for the colliery owner John Grant Morris. It is a large asymmetrical house in two storeys with an attic, constructed in red brick with bands in blue brick and stone, stone dressings, and a tiled roof. It was later used as a school, and then converted into apartments.
A two-storey house in brick with a timber-framed gable.
It is constructed in sandstone with a slate roof. It consists of a castellated entrance with wrought iron gates in an archway, and is attached to a cottage.
A house built by Waterhouse for himself, in brick with much diapering. It is in two storeys with an attic, and has since been used as a students' hall of residence.

Stables and coach house,
Foxhill House

Earley, Berkshire
{{coord|51.4455|-0.9416|name=Stabels and coach house, Foxhill House, Earley}}
Built by Waterhouse for himself, in red brick with blue brick diapering. It is in two storeys with an L-shaped plan. Since used as a students' accommodation.

Stanstead Abbots, Hertfordshire
{{coord|51.8059|0.0055|name=Farmhouse and dairy, Stanstead Abbots}}
A T-plan two-storey house in brick with tiled roofs.

Mossley Hill, Liverpool, Merseyside
{{coord|53.3803|-2.9254|name=Mossley House, Liverpool}}
Built as a mansion for Lloyd Rayner, later incorporated into Mossley Hill Hospital. It is a large, square house constructed in polychromatic brick, and in Gothic style.
A house in limestone with sandstone dressings and a tiled roof. It has two storeys and an attic. Later used as a residential home.
A country house with extensions added in 1882, for Roundell Palmer, 1st Earl of Selborne. The house has since been divided into flats.

Selborne, Hampshire
{{coord|51.0859|-0.8806|name=South Lodge, Blackmoor House, Selborne}}
A country house in limestone with Bath stone dressings and a tiled roof.
A range of buildings round a courtyard with an arched entrance at the corner. Built in limestone with Bath stone and tiled roofs.

Selborne, Hampshire
{{coord|51.0859|-0.8806|name=South Lodge, Blackmoor House, Selborne}}
Buildings around three sides of a courtyard, later converted for residential use.
A house in yellow brick with brownish bands.

Westminster, Greater London
{{coord|51.5113|-0.1488|name=49 Grosvenor Street, Westminster}}
A terraced house built in 1725, heightened and altered by Waterhouse. It is in red brick with a slate roof, and has four storeys, a basement, and dormers in a mansard roof.
File:Eaton Hall c 1880 - Waterhouse's version. Photo by Francis Bedford (died 1894).JPG
A major country house for the 1st Duke of Westminster replacing an earlier hall. It was the most expensive British house to be built in the 19th century, costing £600,000. Demolished in 1963.
Walls and gates with overthrow, Eaton Hall

Cheshire
{{coord|53.1423|-2.8757|name=Walls and gates, Eaton Hall, Cheshire}}
A gateway to the walled garden, {{convert|12|ft|m|1}} high, gate piers, and a pair of gates with an overthrow.

Cheshire
{{coord|53.1413|-2.8776|name=Coach House Court, Eaton Hall, Cheshire}}
A courtyard for the 1st Duke of Westminster containing a coach house, stables, and a riding school.
A lodge in early French Renaissance style for the 1st Duke of Westminster plus gates, piers and screens.

This originated as a country house in about 1705, designed by Thomas Archer for Charles Talbot, 1st Duke of Shrewsbury. It was badly damaged by fire in 1831, then restored and partly rebuilt by Waterhouse for Albert Brassey. It is in Baroque style, constructed in limestone with slate roofs. It has since been converted for use as a hotel. The wings of the house and garden features are listed separately at Grade II.
A brick house in two and three storeys with a tiled roof.

Camden, Greater London
{{coord|51.5171|-0.1169|name=18 Lincoln's Inn Fields, London}}
Built as two houses, later converted into one. In Portland stone with a slate roof. It has four storeys and three gabled dormers.
Lodge to the north of Newsham Park Hospital

Liverpool, Merseyside
{{coord|53.4224|-2.9357|name=Lodge, Newsham Park Hospital, Liverpool}}
A two-storey house in brick with stone dressings and a slate roof.
A country house for the brewer Lt-Col G. F. Greenall at a cost of £15,700. Subsequently extended.
Originally built in 1688 for John Evelyn, the house was rebuilt by Waterhouse, reusing some of its former materials. It is an L-shaped brick house set on a moated site.
A country house built in 1826–31 to which Waterhouse made improvements and additions for William Houldsworth, including a music room, a conservatory, and a private chapel.
File:Pierremont clock tower , Tower Road - geograph.org.uk - 136778.jpg
An addition to the home of Henry Pease, since subdivided into separate units.

This was part of the northern wall of Waterhouse's Eaton Hall, the remainder of which has been demolished. It is in the style of a 16th-century château, constructed in stone with a mansard roof surmounted by iron cresting, and containing dormers.

A country house for Washington Jackson, built in brick with stone dressings. It originally had an east wing and a tower, since demolished. It is in Italianate style. and has three storeys. On the north front is a porte-cochère. The building has since been used as offices.
The east lodge to a country house, built in brick with stone dressings and a slate roof. It has a cruciform plan, and is in Italianate style.
Gateway at East Entrance to Town Thorns
Gateway to a country house, built with stone gatepiers and wrought iron gates.
The south lodge to a country house, built in brick with stone dressings and a slate roof. It has a cruciform plan, and is in Italianate style.
The south lodge to a country house, built in brick with stone dressings and a slate roof. It is in Italianate style.
A building with four ranges enclosing a courtyard; in red brick and half-timbering with tiled roofs, incorporating stables.
A country house constructed in sandstone with slate roofs. It is asymmetrical, with a tower and a porte-cochère. Subsequently converted for use as a school.

Part of a development for the mill-owner William Houldsworth, including a school, the rectory, and St Elisabeth's Church. It is a brick building with stone dressings in Gothic style, and has sash windows.
A villa for T. R. Heatherington in 2½ storeys with a tower. Later used as part of the Xavier College.
Waterhouse made alterations to a large country house dating from about 1620 for Edward Aldam Leatham.
A house for Arthur Ellis, with later additions.
A country house built in 1836, extended by Waterhouse.

Kensington and Chelsea, Greater London
{{coord|51.5056|-0.1962|name=38 Sheffield Terrace, Kensington}}
The only surviving town house by Waterhouse. Built in brick with two storeys and a basement.
This was built as a country house with stables, it is a brick building with stone dressings and tiled roofs. As of 2012 it is one of the academic campuses of Imperial College, London.
A red brick house with a tiled roof, altered in the 20th century.

Blacknest, Hampshire
{{coord|51.4090|-0.6380|name=East Lodge, Silwood Park, Blacknest}}
A red brick house with a tiled roof, altered in the 20th century.

Blacknest, Hampshire
{{coord|51.4165|-0.6497|name=East Lodge, Silwood Park, Blacknest}}
A red brick house with a tiled roof, altered in the 20th century.

Blacknest, Hampshire
{{coord|51.4063|-0.6423|name=South Lodge, Silwood Park, Blacknest}}
A building with an irregular plan, in one and two storeys, constructed in red brick with bands in darker bricks.

Blacknest, Hampshire
{{coord|51.4137|-0.6398|name=Virginia Water Lodge, Silwood Park, Blacknest}}
A red brick house with a tiled roof, altered in the 20th century.
Built as a country house for Lord Wolverton in stone with tiled roofs. It has two storeys with a frontage of nine bays. Later used as a school.
A country house for Charles Myers. Constructed in red brick with painted concrete dressings and tiled roofs. Since converted into flats.
A country house for Alfred Backhouse in French Renaissance style.
A lodge to Dryderdale in sandstone with a T-plan.

This was built as a country house by G. Redmayne to plans drawn up by Waterhouse for Price Waterhouse, and it was later extended. It is constructed in Bargate stone, with brick dressings. The building has since been used as a school.
Built as a house for Alfred Palmer in brick with a tiled roof. Later used as a residential students' home, then as part of the Museum of English Rural Life.
Built as a laundry, this is a two-storey brick building with stone dressings and timber-framed gables.
In simulated stone for the 1st Duke of Westminster.
File:Golden Gates at Eaton Hall Cheshire.JPG
The central gates were made in the early 18th century. Waterhouse added the side gates and screens.
Situated at the south end of the Broad Walk, this is an Italianate structure with three arches between Ionic columns. The central arch contains a Roman altar.

Built for the country house of Lord Wolverton. It is constructed in brick with some timber framing. The entrance has a clock tower and a tourelle. Later used as laboratories and dormitories for Clayesmore School.
A sandstone lodge for the 1st Duke of Westminster in two storeys with a massive central chimney.
A stone lodge for the 1st Duke of Westminster with a four-storey circular tower.

Gate and posts
North Lodge,
Eaton Hall
A wrought iron simple gate {{convert|10|ft|m|1}} high between complex sandstone gateposts.
This is at the north end of the Broad Walk. It is in yellow terracotta in the form of a circularIonic temple surmounted by a shallow dome.
Gates, railings and walls, Eaton Hall
The gates, piers, railings and walls are adjacent to Garden Lodge.

Lodges, walls and garden building,
St Paul's School
This consists of the master's lodge, the porter's lodge, walls and a circular building in the garden.
Built as a vicarage to St Bartholomew's Church, in red brick with decorative features.

Liverpool, Merseyside
{{coord|53.3807|-2.9574|name=Lodge, Turner Memorial Home, Liverpool}}
An L-shaped lodge in stone with a tiled roof, in Gothic style located at the entrance of the drive to the home.
A country house in red brick with diapering and tile hanging, and tiled roofs. Later used as a school.
A new country house, expanded in 1896. In stone with a slate roof; two storeys plus attic; irregular plan.

Cambus, Clackmannanshire, Scotland
{{coord|56.1237|-3.8230|name=Arnsbrae House Lodge, Clackmannanshire}}
A single storey lodge with a slate roof and timber-framed gables.

Cambus, Clackmannanshire, Scotland
{{coord|56.1255|-3.8210|name=Arnsbrae House Lodge, Clackmannanshire}}
A stone building in a single storey with a slate roof and dormers.
A two-storey brick house with a cruciform plan.
A two-storey brick estate lodge with a cruciform plan.
A two-storey brick house with a cruciform plan.
Part of a terrace, built originally as a minister's house, this is a brick building with terracotta dressings; It has a mixture of Romanesque and Gothic styles.
A large irregular house built for the Balston family, owners of Springfield Mill. It is constructed in red brick with yellow brick dressings, and has a tiled roof.
The school house is constructed in red brick with stone dressings and a tiled roof.
A red brick house in 1½ storeys with a T-plan, later divided into two cottages.
A red brick house with some timber framing.
A red brick house in a single storey.
